journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition

title-group.subtitle: The (Bad) Example of Protein Administration in the ICU

contrib-group.aff: Rabin Medical Center, Beilinson Hospital, Petah Tikva, Israel.

author-notes.corresp: Pierre Singer, MD, Institute for Nutrition Research, Department of General Intensive Care, Rabin Medical Center, Beilinson Hospital, Petah Tikva 49100, Affiliated to the Sackler School of Medicine, Tel Aviv University, Israel. Email: psinger@clalit.org.il.

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2013 American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition
permissions.copyright-holder: The American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition

body.p: The gap between the universal recommendations that critically ill patients require 1.3–1.5 g/kg/d of protein and the “real-world” findings showing that most such patients receive not more than 0.8–1.0 g/kg/d in the best cases is puzzling and worrying. Numerous guidelines,1-3 based on clinical studies,4-6 have suggested a protein intake of 1.3–1.5 g/kg/d, which has been defined as the level of intake associated with the lowest rate of catabolism. No additional advantage was observed when higher amounts of protein/amino acids were provided. Many observational studies suggest that achieving these recommendations results in improved outcome.7,8 In practice, as evident in recent, large prospective randomized studies assessing the administration of nutrition using various routes and/or various calorie targets,9-14 protein intake has been largely neglected (see Table 1) and remains below the recommended levels. In this issue of the Journal, Hoffer and Bistrian15 ask the burning question: why is this the case?

caption.p: Protein Intake Inspired by Recent Prospective Nutrition Studies in the Intensive Care Unit.

tr.td: Van den Berghe et al,9 g/kd/d

sec.title: The Definition of Malnutrition
sec.p: Hoffer and Bistrian15 point out that the definition of malnutrition remains problematic. The definition should allow for easy diagnosis, practical screening, and accurate risk prediction. The ESPEN (European Society for Clinical Nutrition and Metabolism) Council and its newly created Nutrition Education Study Group (NESG) have recently discussed this issue (unpublished data), and the need for an improvement of the definition of the disease (malnutrition) and its treatment has been recognized. This has resulted in the proposal of a definition of malnutrition or sarcopenia. The NESG suggested that efforts should be focused on the search for best evidence as well as adopting a consistent terminology (ie, disease-related malnutrition) according to diagnosis criteria. In addition, they suggested that the definition of malnutrition should first include obesity and should use objective diagnostic tools, such as bioimpedance.

sec.title: Failure of Guidelines to Explain the Mechanisms and Pathophysiology: Is This the Problem?
sec.p: The gap between recommendations and implementation may have various explanations. Even if the pathophysiology is well explained, the evidence is based on large prospective randomized studies, the physician is convinced by the evidence, and the caregiver is sure that the physician is prescribing the right therapy, auditing of this practice has revealed that the reality is very different. This reality gap has also been shown in other instances of guideline and evidence-based interventions, such as the prescription of mechanical ventilation using low tidal volumes,16 as suggested by the Surviving Sepsis Campaign: 80% of German intensive care unit (ICU) directors avowed adherence to the guidelines, yet only 2.6% of their patients were actually ventilated with tidal volumes below or equal to 6 mL/ideal body weight (IBW). In a survey auditing the nutrition prescription suggested by Canadian authors,17 the adequacy of enteral nutrition increased from 45.1% to 51.9% for calories and from 44.8% to 51.5% for protein. The authors recognized that this improvement was modest at best. Education appears to be a very important element in changing practice, as demonstrated by a recent Brazilian study18 regarding nutrition therapy. Following the education program for intensive care physicians, there was a significant increase in the early introduction of enteral feeding, a reduction in days of fasting, and an increase in the amount of energy delivered. Surprisingly, protein delivery was not chosen as a therapeutic end point. Ideally, education programs should include optimal communication strategies targeted to different groups so that the application to malnutrition may be as successful as that seen for diabetes and obesity.19,20 Protocols and audits are other effective tools. In the past decades, hospital administrations have been required to undergo accreditation processes. This has resulted in increased nutrition screening, the recognition of malnutrition as a real problem and its inclusion in problem lists, and the requirement for prescribing nutrition therapy where diagnosed. Decisions made by health authorities and states for malnutrition screening have been effective in the Netherlands and in Belgium. In Denmark, nurses have played a central role in promoting nutrition, demonstrating that effective implementation can be achieved. The Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) initiative21 is another example of the implementation of evidence-based practice, including no fasting (and, therefore, starvation) prior to surgery and removal of nasogastric tubes immediately after surgery in most cases. In addition and importantly, a close interplay between the active center and an audit system ensures improvement in practice as well as in outcome.

sec.title: Calorie Target and Not Protein Target
sec.p: Several surveys have audited the calorie and protein recommendations, prescription, and administration in ICUs. The results are very disappointing. In a worldwide survey, calorie and protein administration reached around 45%–55% of that prescribed, far below the recommendations.17 One explanation is the lack of nutrition knowledge of nonnutritionist physicians. The main target for nutrition prescriptions appears to be based on caloric requirements so that physicians prefer standard enteral and parenteral formulas based on the amount of calories they prescribe. The protein intake appears to be a secondary target despite all the evidence and recommendations. In addition, although most enteral and parenteral products available for critically ill patients are able to supply the calorie target, they do not provide the protein target. This was clearly shown in the supplemental parenteral nutrition study and Tight Calorie Control Study (TICACOS),12,13 which administered energy according to indirect calorimetry, whereas protein was administered according to the available products. The TICACOS study and other centers22 have demonstrated that the intervention of a dietitian and the support of a computerized information system23 could be very helpful in recognizing the daily calorie deficit and evaluating the gap between the protein target and the amount achieved in practice on a day-by-day basis. This intervention may increase the likelihood of providing an adequate amount of both calories and protein to ICU patients.

The lack of ability to evaluate nitrogen requirements is another barrier in prescribing an adequate amount of protein. Biolo24 proposed choosing markers according to the main aims of the amino acid provision. Thus, if lean body mass is targeted, dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry, bioimpedance, or magnetic resonance imaging measurements might be used. Regarding glutamine supplementation, protein levels might be monitored and for oxidative stress, glutathione, and other markers.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The factors resulting in the nonimplementation of recommendations and protocols appear to be multiple: health professionals who are resistant to change, the large workload, a lack of awareness, and a poor bulk of evidence. This is aggravated by slow administrative processes and inadequacy of presently available industry products.24 Understanding the reasons behind behavior change failures is the first step toward changing management processes.24 The second step is using communication and teamwork to involve all appropriate health professionals in the planned new process, emphasizing the benefits of such change. When this is achieved, permanent evaluation of the daily routine and acknowledgment of any achievements are mandatory to freeze the process. This theory developed by Lewin26 could pave the way to successful implementation of ICU nutrition recommendations.

fn.p: This article originally appeared online on March 11, 2013.
